isis.stitle: TSI 06-12-17 - Ultra Low Sulfur Diesel (ULSD) Effects on Seals

subjectgroup.subject: Ultra Low Sulfur Diesel (ULSD) Effects on Seals

geninfo.para: This TSI applies to all International® diesel engines, 2006 model year and older.

The U.S. EPA has mandated the use of Ultra Low Sulfur Diesel (ULSD) in on-road applications. Replacement of Low Sulfur Diesel (LSD) with ULSD has already begun at most fuel suppliers and will be completed by October 15, 2006.

Depending on the refinery process and crude oil specifics, ULSD may have less aromatic content than LSD. While a lower aromatic level is acceptable according to the ASTM diesel fuel standard, it may cause fuel system seals in older engines to shrink and potentially leak. Older engines are susceptible to shrinkage because their seals may have lost elasticity over time. Engines that have not run for long periods of time with LSD or have been solely run on ULSD, are at minimal risk.

To avoid fuel leaks when changing from LSD to ULSD, consider replacing fuel system seals on engines that have been using LSD for a prolonged period of time. If leakage is experienced when using ULSD, all seals in the fuel system should be replaced, including the fuel lift/transfer pump and the seals in the fuel filter header.
